captions.text:
00:02
HELEN: I could feel my mood going lower and

lower and I reached the point where I couldn't
live anymore.

00:06
COMM: Happy and smiley she might me now but

a horrific ordeal would leave Helen Galsworthy
without legs

00:15
COMM: At the age of 18, she became a double

amputee after lying down in front of a train
in attempt to take her own life.

00:23
HELEN: I remember the day it was um the 19th

June 2007 and it was a really bright, sunny
day. it was the one day where I sort of felt

okay and that was because I knew I was going
to die, I didn't feel scared at the time I

just felt completely at piece but obviously
it was not meant to be.

00:38
HELEN: When I woke up in the hospital my mum

was next to me and I said to her I've lost
my legs haven't I and she just held my hand

and said yes and I just felt absolutely devastated
and not only sad that it had happened, I felt

stupid, I felt like I mess up everything in
my life and I even messed up my own suicide
attempt.

00:56
COMM: Helen narrowly escaped death and now
the loss of her legs bought new challenges.

01:02
HELEN: I adjusted to life as an amputee quite

slowly it took me a really long time, I'd
see all my friends go off to university, enjoying

their lives and I just thought that, that
was something I was never going to achieve
now.

01:13
COMM: But 5 years later, Helen found a new
purpose in life when she became a mum to Thomas.

01:20
HELEN: Becoming a mum changed my life in the

way that it suddenly wasn't just about me
anymore, its really simple things like his

little smile, his laugh, the way he'll look
into my eyes and its just, now he's 2 years

old he's got such a lovely little personality
and he makes me happy everyday

01:36
COMM: Being a double amputee can be hard work
with a toddler.

01:40
HELEN: It'll be the little things like he'll

be playing down on his matt and I'll want
to get down and sit with him and once I'm

down I find it very hard to get back up and
just all the practical things like I cant

chase after him in the garden or at the park.
One thing I do dread about the future is telling

Thomas what happened to his mum and when he's
older I shall wait until he is old enough

to understand, I really do panic about how
I'm going to tell him about what happened
to my legs.

02:05
COMM: But now she has the help and support
of current boyfriend, Will.

02:10
WILL: I'm quite helpful and I do a lot with

Helen, I don't find it difficult at all, I
don't look at Helen as being disabled, I look
at Helen as Helen.

02:22
COMM: Today Helen doesn't let anything hold

her back. She's studying for a degree in Criminology
and has even sky dived for an amputee charity

and now she wants to help others who have
suffered with depression

02:34
HELEN: It's a great passion of mine to help

other people with mental health problems,
i volunteered for charities such as "young

minds" and "a time to change" and I'm currently
helping to start a charity with other mums

who have suffered post-natal illnesses. i'm
looking forward to seeing Thomas grow up and

I'm looking forward to holding to a job and
having a happy life with my partner. I like

to believe that everything happens for a reason
and that could be why I survived.

title: Amputee Mum Finds Happiness After Suicide Attempt

comments.author: Funky Gamer

comments.text:
This woman is absolutely beautiful. I know exactly how it feels to be happy 
at the thought that when things get really hard, I can take control and end 
it all. The teenage years were the hardest but even now I feel like there 
must be something about some people's brain and thought patterns that 
allows or causes them to lean towards suicidal ideation at the drop of a 
hat, while others don't even see it as an option. She literally found a 
purpose in life too and a true challenge to wake up to and master every 
single day. Maybe we all need to conjure one of these up so we don't sweat 
the smaller stuff.﻿

comments.text:
Drink: Aim to drink three litres of fluid daily. This will help move the 
lymph and support kidney detoxification. Choose from pure spring water, 
fresh vegetable juice and herbal detox teas. Or make your own brew by 
mixing one or a combination of Dandelion root and nettle, cleavers, 
calendula, burdock and red clover. Add one teaspoon of the dried herbs to a 
cup of boiling water. Leave to steep for five minutes, strain and drink.﻿

fibre body brush, brush the skin with firm circular strokes before you step 
into the shower. Start from the feet and hands, moving up the legs and 
towards the arms, avoiding the delicate area of throat and face, and any 
rash or sore spots. Then jump in the shower. Finish your shower with a 
one-minute burst cold water which brings the blood circulation to the skin.
